title: The Underground Map of the Elements
html:
A Chat and Waffles Chemistry Blog

Chemistry Blog

  • Home
  • Chemistry Dictionary
  • FAQ

The Underground Map of the Elements

August 27, 2013 •By Mark •In chemical education, fun

My son loves trains. So I came up with a train related twist to an inspection of the periodic table. We sat and cut up a copy of the table and then rearranged each element as a ‘station’ on an underground rail system. Each line represents a characteristic shared by the elements on that line.

After (quite) a few drafts, and more time than I care to admit, we ended up with this.

It was constructed with the help of Metro Map Creator (no way I could have done it without this neat web app). If anyone fancies building some more lines I’ll happily send you the saved file (share using a creative commons attribution, non-commercial, share a like license) .

Let me know if you spot any errors.

Edit:

Thanks to Shaun, Max, Ian, Mitch, Yul, Labrat and Stu (alway handy to have a Nature Chemistry editor check your work)  for spotting some mistakes. All corrected now.

Now on version 1.4. New line added, to show elements that were discovered via synthesis and then found in nature.

Tags: elements•map•metro•network•Periodic Table•transit

Share this post

Tweet
Mark

Mark Lorch has PhD in biochemist and is a Professor of Chemistry and Science Communication at the University of Hull, UK. As well as research, teaching and blogging he can sometimes be found 'science busking' on the streets of Yorkshire. Oh, and he tweets @mark_lorch

21 Comments

  1. mitch says:
    On August 27, 2013 @ 8:14 pm

    Awesome, but Technetium has no stable isotope as well.

  2. Mark says:
    On August 27, 2013 @ 9:50 pm

    On yeh.

    Tweeps have also pointed out typos in Cesium and Vanadium. I’ll sort them out later.

  3. David P says:
    On August 28, 2013 @ 8:02 am

    Very awesome. Has it helped your son learn the elements?
    (My son loves trains too so I should love to get a copy).

    • Mark says:
      On August 29, 2013 @ 5:05 am

      Feel free to print out a copy. Once I’m sure I’ve got all the clinches ironed out I’ll post a high res copy for people to print.

      Yes my son did learn something about the elements. Mainly via the process of compiling the map, and now he wants to take it into school to show his class mates. So I think its achieved its objective.

  4. Max says:
    On August 28, 2013 @ 8:08 am

    Lanthanoids is misspelled ‘Lantanoids’. Furthermore, they and their cousins are usually referred to as Lanthanides and Actinides, but either is acceptable.

  5. mitch says:
    On August 28, 2013 @ 11:05 am

    This might work well as a board game.

  6. Mark says:
    On August 28, 2013 @ 12:13 pm

    Thanks Max, sorted now. Glad to see peer review is working well here!

    Mitch, what spotting my mistakes 🙂 God knows there’s enough of them. Dyslexics of the world untie!

  7. Saber says:
    On August 28, 2013 @ 12:43 pm

    This is very cool! Would you mind if I downloaded and printed out a copy? This would make a cool poster for my dorm room =)

    • Mark says:
      On August 28, 2013 @ 11:09 pm

      Sure, the more dorm rooms with a copy of it the better.

  8. John says:
    On August 29, 2013 @ 4:46 am

    Great job with the map. My only nitpicking would be to pit Bismuth one stop up on the “no stable isotopes” metro line.

    • Mark says:
      On August 29, 2013 @ 5:02 am

      Good point, will do. Although with a half life a billion times the age of the Universe it might have to have a unique branch line.

  9. Shaun says:
    On August 30, 2013 @ 4:51 am

    Two more typos: Holmium and Flerovium

    This is a great idea! Very very cool.

  10. Pingback: Rethinking the Jablonski Diagram » Chemistry Blog

  11. XY says:
    On November 15, 2013 @ 9:27 pm

    Can you please send me a copy? This is awesome! Thank you!

  12. Pingback: Fighting Spiders and the London Underground Map

  13. Pingback: The Underground Map of the Elements | Mark Lorch | Science | theguardian.com « The Wiert Corner – irregular stream of stuff

  14. Pingback: Mapa dos elementos químicos | Tabela Periódica

  15. Mark Adler says:
    On March 26, 2015 @ 9:26 am

    My son is a chemistry AND subway map nerd and would love to play around with your saved file. Can you please send it?

    • Mark says:
      On March 27, 2015 @ 3:16 am

      Sure thing. Here’s a link to the text file https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uc4TuyGb1KUm78g9bfcnfzt1Ed6gIUTsWF0Dxnaz7ME/edit?usp=sharing

      He’ll need to copy and past it into the Metro Map Creator.

  16. Pingback: The Underground Map of the Elements – now with Nh, Mc, Ts & Og » Chemistry Blog

  17. Pingback: La metropolitana degli elementi  – apoMaio
